definition[0]: to think or say that something is possible or likely to happen, especially something good
example[0]: Negotiators aren’t holding out much hope of a peaceful settlement.
note[0]: not hold out much hope/hold out little hope
example[1]: alternative methods which hold out the promise of improved health
note[1]: hold out the prospect/promise of something
definition[1]: if a supply of something holds out, there is still some left
example[2]: Water supplies won’t hold out much longer.
definition[2]: to continue to successfully defend a place that is being attacked
example[3]: The rebels held out for another night but then fresh forces arrived.
definition[3]: to try to prevent yourself from doing something that someone is trying to force you to do
example[4]: I didn’t know how much longer I could hold out against their relentless questioning.
